entry.title: Scraping, Cleaning, and Importing, Part 1
entry.summary: Before I can start parsing the address entries into distinct fields, I have to get the OCRed directories from their home on Hathitrust and put them into my main data frame. I've already done that for most of the nineteenth-century New York City directories using a three-step process of scraping, cleaning, and importing the data. Before wrapping that up, I want to take a snapshot of this process for my blog. I'll begin with a general overview.

.ansi-cyan-intense-bg { background-color: #258F8F; }

.ansi-white-bg { background-color: #C5C1B4; }

.ansi-white-intense-bg { background-color: #A1A6B2; }

.ansi-bold { font-weight: bold; }
</style>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Before I can start parsing the address entries into distinct fields, I have to get the OCRed directories from their home on <a href="https://hathitrust.org">Hathitrust</a> and put them into my main data frame. I've already done that for most of the nineteenth-century New York City directories using a three-step process of scraping, cleaning, and importing the data. Before wrapping that up, I want to take a snapshot of this process for my blog. I'll begin with a general overview.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [1]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">os</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read_pickle</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'../blogdata/catalog.p'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'total_pages'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'seq_end'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'imported'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'processed'</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>As I've discussed in an earlier blog entry, I used <a href="https://www.crummy.com/software/BeautifulSoup/">BeautifulSoup</a> to create a 'catalog' data frame that contains information about each of the 111 New York City directories that I've found in HathiTrust. In addition to a large number of nineteenth-century directories, the catalog data frame contains quite a few entries from the late 1700s and the early 1900s. Since those aren't of interest to me at the moment, I'll exclude them from my working data frame. I'll also limit the working data frame to the seven columns relevant for understanding the process of scraping, cleaning, and importing the Hathitrust directories: the directory title, the publisher, the year it was published, the total number of pages in the digital version of that directory, and the number of pages that have already been scraped, cleaned, and imported:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pub_year</span> <span class="o">></span> <span class="mi">1799</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">&</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pub_year</span> <span class="o"><</span> <span class="mi">1900</span><span class="p">)]</span>
<span class="n">select_cols</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'title'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'publisher'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'pub_year'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'total_pages'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'scraped'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'cleaned'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'imported'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">df</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">select_cols</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Next, I'll transform those column names into a more user-friendly version for display here:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [4]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">display_names</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Title'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Publisher'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Year'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Total Pages'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Scraped'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Cleaned'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Imported'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">columns</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">display_names</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Scraping-Hathitrust">Scraping Hathitrust<a class="anchor-link" href="#Scraping-Hathitrust">¶</a></h4><p>The scraping process grabs each OCRed page from each directory in the catalog and stores it locally as a text file with html markup. Scraping a single directory takes a fair amount of time (about two seconds per page; it adds up, particularly as the directories get longer over time). Happily only the directories from the 1890s remain:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [5]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">unscraped</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Scraped</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"</span><span class="se">\n\n</span><span class="s2">Number of directories waiting to be scraped: "</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">sum</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">unscraped</span><span class="p">)))</span>
<span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">unscraped</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sort_values</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Year'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>

Number of directories waiting to be scraped: 4
</pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[5]:</div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>

<td>380</td>
<td>0</td>
<td>0</td>
<td>0</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>70</th>
<td>New York city directory</td>
<td>Trow</td>
<td>1896</td>
<td>1750</td>

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<div style="font-size: 12px !important; color: #4B0082;"><em>As a sidenote, it's worth noting the wide variation in the length of the four directories above. The 1890 and 1895 publications are suprisingly short at less than 500 pages each--a length more typical of directories from the 1820s. By the 1890s, New York City was a bonafide metropolis with a <a href="https://www.census.gov/population/www/documentation/twps0027/tab12.txt">population of approximately 1.5 million</a>. That, combined with the addition of advertisements, meant that most New York City address directories of that decade had 1500 pages or more.

<p>So what's going on here? As their (truncated) titles suggest, the 1890 and 1895 publications above were business directories, not residential ones. It's fun data to have, so there's no harm in scraping, cleaning, and importing the business directories too, but I'll exclude them from the main analysis later.</p></em></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In addition to the four directories that need scraping, I also have some recently-scraped directories waiting in my cleaning queue. These directories exist locally as text files, but are full of html markup. Thankfully, Hathitrust was judicious and consistent in their use of "id" and "class" tags, so I can easily remove the markup and other extraneous text using <a href="https://www.crummy.com/software/BeautifulSoup/">BeautifulSoup</a>. Currently, I have four directories waiting to be cleaned:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [6]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">unclean</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Scraped</span> <span class="o">></span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">&</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Cleaned</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"</span><span class="se">\n\n</span><span class="s2">Number of scraped directories waiting to be cleaned: "</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">sum</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">unclean</span><span class="p">)))</span>
<span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">unclean</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sort_values</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Year'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>

</pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[6]:</div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Cleaning-&-Importing">Cleaning & Importing<a class="anchor-link" href="#Cleaning-&-Importing">¶</a></h4><p>The cleaning process produces a collection of text files, each file containing OCRed text from one scanned page. Blank pages--pages that had no OCRed text at all--are omitted during the cleaning process. Once cleaned, the files will be imported line-by-line into an existing Pandas data frame. Currently, I have fourteen scraped and cleaned directories waiting to be imported:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [7]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">ready_for_import</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Cleaned</span> <span class="o">></span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">&</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Imported</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"</span><span class="se">\n\n</span><span class="s2">Number of cleaned directories waiting to be imported: "</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">sum</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ready_for_import</span><span class="p">)))</span>
<span class="n">df</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">ready_for_import</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sort_values</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Year'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>

</pre>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The fourteen directories above are now ready to join the seventy-four directories that have already been imported. Currently that data frame has over six million rows, each representing one line of text from a directory. Once all of the ninetheenth-century directories have been imported into the main data frame, I can move on to the next phase of this project: parsing each address line into distinct columns ('last name', 'first name', 'occupation', etc.).</p>
<p>But before doing that, I'll need to determine which of the rows in the main data frame represent address entries and which represent other types of text. As this print-out from the main data frame shows, many of the rows are in fact addresses:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [8]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">address_sample</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read_pickle</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'../blogdata/address_sample.p'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">index</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">row</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">address_sample</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iterrows</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="s2">": "</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">row</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">entry</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">1</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>0: Clark Barney, shoemaker, 86 Mulberry
1: Clark Daniel, laborer, Eighth c. Av. C
2: Clark Dennis, laborer, 64 Gouverneur
3: Clark Ebenezer, strawedgings, 53 Factory
4: Clark Edward, paper carrier, 168 Clinton
5: Clark Edward, laborer, r. 79 W. 18th
6: Clark Edward, (col'd) porter, 13 York
7: Clark George, machinist, r. 37 Broome
8: Clark George, meat.curer, 276 Mulberry
9: Clark Hezekiah, carman, E. 25th n. Av. 1
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>But many directory pages contain no addresses at all. These include the introduction and table of contents, and supplemental pages, such as weather tables, informational essays, and advertisements. The rows produced from these pages will need to be excluded from the analysis:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [10]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">suppl_sample</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read_pickle</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'../blogdata/suppl_sample.p'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">index</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">row</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">suppl_sample</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iterrows</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="s2">": "</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">row</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">entry</span><span class="p">[:</span><span class="mi">80</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="s1">'...'</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">i</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">1</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>0: This great engraving, the fruit of four years' labor and got up at an expense of...
1: and it staids, beyond a cavil, among the proudest monuments of the Fine Arts....
2: “Washington City, January 20, 1848....
3: 2 <n ºf le3 e3, go 4- ºr s&s 4\, ºr a... 4: zºs - after may 1st, 1848, at 205 broadway. §... 5: º, mr. a. would reſer to the distinguished reputation of the hoºse of - %. ,... 6: *5 neur orders for any prints, either old or of late publication, will be *... 7: 9.4% “agréez, messieurs messinceres complimens et l'assurance forwarded to siirº... 8: agents-rushton, clark & co., 110 broadway and 10 astor house; 83 broadway; 2 par... 9: ances, and an eye to economy, to... < pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Fortunately, there are a number of ways to use Python to isolate address entries from other types of text. I'll be talking about those in a future blog entry.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>

entry.title: Introducing the NYC Directory Project
entry.summary: The NYC Directory Project uses Python to extract data from nineteenth-century address directories that have been scanned and made publicly available on Hathitrust.org. The final result will be a demographic and geocoded dataset that can be searched and analyzed to learn more about the residents of New York City in the 1800s.

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The NYC Directory Project uses Python to extract data from nineteenth-century address directories that have been scanned and made publicly available on <a href="https://www.hathitrust.org">Hathitrust.org</a>. The final result will be a demographic and geocoded dataset that can be searched and analyzed to learn more about the residents of New York City in the 1800s.</p>
<p>Browsing through directories on <a href="https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Search/Home?type%5B%5D=subject&lookfor%5B%5D=%22%20New%20York%20%28N.Y.%29%20Directories.%22&filter%5B%5D=topicStr%3ANew%20York%20%28N.Y.%29%20Directories&ft=">Hathitrust</a> and at the <a href="https://www.nypl.org/blog/2016/09/21/new-york-city-directories-free-online">New York Public Library</a> and other sites, I was intrigued at the sheer quantity of data embedded there and struck by what could be learned and accomplished by using code to clean and structure it. Historical sources such as the <a href="https://archive.org/details/us_census">United States Federal Census</a> and the <a href="https://familysearch.org/search/collection/1491284">New York State Census</a> provide a useful picture of past New York City residents, but census data exists, at best, only at five-year intervals and prior to 1850 the census is <a href="https://www.thoughtco.com/digging-details-from-us-census-records-1421771">notably vague</a>.</p>
<p>Address directories have long been an alternative source of information for historians and genealogists. The scanning of address directories by Google, Archive.org, and others made them widely available so that getting access to them no longer required a physical trip to the repository that owned them. Even in digital format, however, they remained stubbornly analog, used primarily for locating individuals whose names were already known in an alphabetical index--just as originally intended. The production of text versions using OCR (optical character recognition) freed the directories from the tyranny of alphabetical order and made it possible to search the text by name, street, or occupation, for example.</p>
<p>Unfortunately, even with OCR, the utility of the address directories remains limited. You can search them, but you can't analyze them, and the inconsistent quality of OCR makes searching the directories a game of “hit or miss.” As the images below show, the quality of OCR output can be remarkably accurate:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>

</sub>
</figcaption>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>...or problematically poor:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<div align="center">
<figure>
<img alt="scanned directory page" src="images/NYC-1844.png" />
</figure>
<figure>
<img alt="OCR text" src="images/NYC-1844-ocr.png" />
<figcaption>
<sub><em>The New York City Directory, 1844/45</em>, at 
                <a href="https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=osu.32435056191521;view=1up;seq=217;size=150">Hathitrust</a>
</sub>
</figcaption>
</figure>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The NYC Directory Project is an effort to enhance the value of historical address directories by using <a href="https://www.python.org/about/gettingstarted/">Python</a> to access, clean, and structure the text, and by using statistical inference to identify different address formats and to fix OCR errors where possible. This process will make searching a single directory considerably more effective, but more importantly it will allow for the systematic analysis of data within and across address directories, providing an annual snapshot of New York City as it was (or at least, as it appeared in these directories; as I will discuss in a future post, the directories were far from a comprehensive accounting of the city’s population). And because address directories, happily, used fairly consistent formats, this project is portable: the same code--with the inevitable tweaking--can be used to unlock the past of other cities as well.</p>
<p>While this project contributes to a larger effort by Historiscope to extract and disseminate demographically meaningful data from publicly available digitized documents, it's also inspired by some personal goals. I began this project in part as a means to learn and practice writing Python code, a tool I just recently added to my wheelhouse. I <a href="mailto:info@historiscope.org">welcome and encourage</a> suggestions and corrections.</p>
<p>Also, somewhere in those directories are the friends and relatives of my elusive ancestor William Peck Sims, a New York City wheelwright born around 1810 and a lifelong resident of old New York. Using the Python-enhanced version of these directories, I hope to get to know him and his world a little better.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>

</sub>

</div>
</div>

    mathjaxscript.id = 'mathjaxscript_pelican_#%@#$@#';
    mathjaxscript.type = 'text/javascript';
    mathjaxscript.src = '//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/mathjax/2.7.1/MathJax.js?config=TeX-AMS-MML_HTMLorMML';
    mathjaxscript[(window.opera ? "innerHTML" : "text")] =
        "MathJax.Hub.Config({" +
        "    config: ['MMLorHTML.js']," +
        "    TeX: { extensions: ['AMSmath.js','AMSsymbols.js','noErrors.js','noUndefined.js'], equationNumbers: { autoNumber: 'AMS' } }," +
        "    jax: ['input/TeX','input/MathML','output/HTML-CSS']," +
        "    extensions: ['tex2jax.js','mml2jax.js','MathMenu.js','MathZoom.js']," +
        "    displayAlign: 'center'," +
        "    displayIndent: '0em'," +
        "    showMathMenu: true," +
        "    tex2jax: { " +
        "        inlineMath: [ ['$','$'] ], " +
        "        displayMath: [ ['$$','$$'] ]," +
        "        processEscapes: true," +
        "        preview: 'TeX'," +
        "    }, " +
        "    'HTML-CSS': { " +
        " linebreaks: { automatic: true, width: '95% container' }, " +
        "        styles: { '.MathJax_Display, .MathJax .mo, .MathJax .mi, .MathJax .mn': {color: 'black ! important'} }" +
        "    } " +
        "}); ";
    (document.body || document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0]).appendChild(mathjaxscript);
}
</script>
